title: 105_s1642
content:
The "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1998" aims to streamline and simplify over 600 different Federal financial assistance programs to improve the delivery of services to the public by reducing duplicative, burdensome, and conflicting administrative requirements. The purposes of the Act are to improve the effectiveness of Federal financial assistance programs, simplify application and reporting requirements, enhance service delivery to the public, and promote coordination among service providers. In this Act, key definitions include the Director as the head of the Office of Management and Budget, Federal agency as any agency defined under title 5 of the United States Code, Federal financial assistance as assistance provided to non-Federal entities, local government as a political subdivision of a State, non-Federal entity as a State, local government, or nonprofit organization, and nonprofit organization as an entity primarily operated for scientific purposes. An organization is defined as a non-profit entity operated for public interest, using proceeds to maintain its operations. A State includes various regions and governmental entities. A tribal government refers to an Indian tribe. An Indian tribe is defined as a tribal government, as per section 7501(a)(9) of title 31, United States Code, which also defines a uniform administrative rule as a government-wide rule for achieving national policy objectives across multiple Federal financial assistance programs. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Each Federal agency must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment to streamline application procedures, participate in interagency processes, use a common application system, designate a lead official, allow electronic applications, ensure timely reporting, and set annual goals. Each agency must provide high-quality information in response to Federal reporting requirements and establish annual goals to measure performance. The Director may grant extensions for agencies unable to comply, and agencies must publish their plans for public comment. Each Federal agency must develop a plan under subsection (a) and submit it to the Director and Congress. The plan must be open to public comment and agencies should hold public forums. The lead official must consult with non-Federal entities during plan development and implementation. Annual reports on plan implementation and agency performance must be submitted to Congress. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall direct, coordinate, and assist Federal agencies in establishing a common application and reporting system for Federal financial assistance programs. This system includes a common application, a common system for managing funding, and uniform administrative rules across different Federal agencies. The Director may designate a lead agency and use interagency working groups to streamline and simplify Federal financial assistance administrative procedures, improve coordination of information sharing, and enhance the quality of information received by Federal agencies from recipients of financial assistance. Agencies are required to submit plans and reports for review. The Director may use interagency working groups to assist in carrying out responsibilities. Agencies must submit information and reports for review. The Director can exempt agencies from the Act if they have few financial assistance programs, with exempted agencies listed on OMB's website. The Director will contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act, with input from various entities. The evaluation will assess the Act's effectiveness, agency performance, and coordination among different levels of government and organizations. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF INFORMATION: The Act allows Federal agencies to gather necessary information for financial integrity reviews of activities receiving Federal assistance. 

SEC. 9. JUDICIAL REVIEW: No judicial review is permitted for compliance with the Act, and no rights or benefits can be enforced through administrative or judicial actions.

SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS: The Act does not override statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET: The Act will be effective upon enactment and will expire five years later. The Act was passed by the Senate on October 12, 1998, and attested by Secretary Gary Sisco.
